description.narrative:
Reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from the use of fossil fuel for thermal energy generation in the Sri Lanka industrial sector
Removal of barriers to the realization of sustainable biomass plantation and adoption of biomassbased energy technologies in Sri Lanka

No of companies operating BETs by endofproject EOP
Number of proposed BET investments by EOP
Total installed capacity and resulting fossil fuel reduction and direct GHG emission reduction of these projects by EOP
share of biomass in energy mix by EOP
Annual fossil fuel consumption reduction starting Year 1
Cumulative GHG emission reduction by EOP

comment.narrative: Limited experience with BETs in industry

At least 12 companies are operating BETs and another 12 companies have detailed feasibility studies completed or started installation of gasifier systems by the end of the project postproject direct emission reduction in particular gasification with total capacity of 257 MWth and 1 MWe resulting in fossil fuel savings of about 295178 GJ annually 4680 MWh of electricity and direct emission reduction cumulative over 10 year lifetime of 252 ktCO2
Indirect emission reduction impacts between 609 bottomup and 1378 ktCO2 top down

There are 10 companies identified as per the inception report who have pledged cofinancing in relation to the outcome 4 It was expected to add more partners
Of these three gasifier systems two Aitken Spence hotels and Apollo Marine International Ltd are in operation and had initiated activities before the project had become operational The plantation companies listed however are more concerned about implementing fuelwood plantations and improving supply chains Almost all the tea processing factories listed now use biomass but for drying purposes not as gasifiers The industrial sector Brandix has implemented a new plant but not with biomass gasifier
There are six other entities too who were mentioned in the inception report as probable candidates Of them one company Lion Brewery is already considering installing a biomass run plant but not opting for gasifier technology
However there are a number of other companies that have already installed and some more have planned to introduce the BETs for thermal energy requirements during the project period without project interventions Majority of them are not Gasifiers as the project has proposed It is noted that the industry prefers other technologies direct fired boilers industrial heaters over gasifiers to meet their thermal needs Therefore project needs to review the technology selection to support industry requirements
This concern was highlighted at the project core group meeting as well as the last steering committee meeting and it was suggested to take up the matter at the MTR time and propose appropriate changes to reflect the changed baseline situation and follow the recommendations therein
With the MTR recommendations the project is working on updating the activities and Outputs Subsequently related indicators will be reflected in the project log frame Technology related issues will be addressed as well during this adaptive management process Industry preferences are in biomass fired conventional boilers with modern controlling and feeding systems with cogeneration and trigeneration options industrial dryers etc
In order to select committed partners for demonstration projects Project has initiated discussion with the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce not gone ahead with newspaper advertisement as proposed earlier as the advertisement by SLSEA for registering supply chain operators received a poor response Once the technology concern is addressed to project expects to work with the industry on assisting in feasibility studies and technology demonstration

comment.narrative: Report on pros and cons on fossil fuel subsidies published by year 1 resulting in a at least one policy paper and presentation to Treasury officials through SLSEA

The fossil fuel subsidies existed during project development period has been withdrawn But there was no firm fossil fuel pricing methodology nor policy governing it in operation but fuel prices have been brought up as a political issue Project has been working on obtaining services of a suitable consultant to carry out a study but this volatile situation was not the opportune time
The establishment of the new government in January 2015 the fossil fuel prices have been changed and the government is planning to introduce transparent cost reflective pricing formula for fossil fuel as well Now the country is again at a verge of parliamentary election through which a new government will be established The subsidy effect if any will be analyzed to take appropriate future actions when the current scenario is stabilized

With reference to 2014 PIR the delayed start of the project was explained and Considering the time factor for developing a certification scheme during the project lifetime Lead Technical Officer of the project decided to go for a process of developing criteria and indicators for sustainably produced fuel wood Through a LoA Sri Lanka Standards Institution SLSI was assigned to develop criteria and Indicators for sustainably produce fuel wood First working group meeting held in May 2015 to draft the initial document This will be reviewed and updated during the next working group meeting It is expected to initiate the pilot the scheme by mid2016
At the time the project was designed the Coconut Cultivation Board operated a subsidy scheme of LKR 4000ac for growing Gliricidia in coconut lands However in 2011 this subsidy scheme had been withdrawn due to poor uptake by the farmers
During the Inception Workshop CCB had agreed to revive a projectsupported pilot subsidy scheme for Gliricidia cultivation in the coconut triangle districts of Gampaha Kurunegala and Puttalam There was no followup on this initiative and the CCB had not launched this programme
The project is following up with CCB who agreed to explore the possibility of incorporating Gliricidia as a component in its animal husbandry subsidy scheme and to explore ways of mobilizing the communities under the CCBs Kapruka Societies to enhance Gliricidia cultivation

description.narrative: Improved confidence among industrial and banking sector on the feasibility stability and economic benefits of sustainable fuel wood supply chains
Number of supply chains developed in a feasible way

comment.narrative: Supply chains meet constraints
At least six supply chains developed that are sustainable on the longer term

The study on the current status of biomass energy has been concluded This study has recorded that there are well established supply chains feeding industrial zones of Biyagama Horana and Seethawaka supplying 820 tons of biomass per day as well as several large industries located outside industrial zones and tea factories Fuel is supplied as mainly wood logs wood chips and saw dustrice husk Several facilities that convert wood logs to chips also established to feed the demand Prices of different types of fuel and supply mechanisms have been recorded The major concerns now prevail in the industry are sustainability of the wood supplies modes of optimizing existing chains to get the best outcome from the resources involved and identification of further mechanizations to improve the efficiency of operation and quality of the product This information will be used to plan future activities in a more focussed manner
SLSEA has published a newspaper and web advertisement to get supply chain operators listed with them but received a poor response However with the Trainings and awareness activities conducted the project has identified key players However smaller grass root level organizations need more attention and that gap will be filled by the Trainers trained at the TOT on supply chain development SLSEA is planning activities on this regard

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Indicator 1: Manual is available to train government officers and volunteer on Climate and Disaster sensitive Village resource Management Plans
Indicator 2: Number of Grama Nildari -level mobilisers train on participatory climate and disaster sensitive Village DP/ VRMP process
Indicator 3: No of stakeholder groups reporting enhanced awareness of climate change risks and adaptation measures at national, district and village levels
Indicator 4: Number of government departments providing regular in-house training programs embedded with climate resilient planning tools.
Indicator 5: Number of people having access (quantity, quality and time) to water throughout year

comment.narrative: Baseline 1: Currently no manual available Baseline 2: 0 Baseline 3: 90% of the stakeholder groups do have zero awareness on climate change risks and adaptation measures. stakeholder groups -Officers of National Planning, Ministry of Finance and Ministry of Economic Development -Divi Neguma Task Force at National and District level -District Planning Units -Divisional Planning Units -Village mobilisers-communities in risk prone GN units Baseline 4: Except Irrigation Department all the other line department and ministries do not have climate resilient planning tools in regular training programs adequately Baseline 5: the beneficiaries living in the command areas of the targeted 15 tanks do not have year-round access to quality water

Target 1: Manual is available Target 2: 200 mobilizers trained on participatory climate and disaster sensitive Village Development Planning/ VRMP process Target 3: 5 stakeholder groups (115 individuals) Target 4: 2 departments provide in-house training programmes embedded with climate change adaptation Target 5: at least 17,500 people have access to water throughout the year

Result1: Resilient village framework was developed in collaboration with a broad range of stakeholders under the leadership of Ministry of Disaster Management. Training manual was developed based on the resilient village framework. Technical focus of the resilient village development planning training manual is to reduce the vulnerability. Completed by 2015
Result 2: 300 Grama Niladari level mobilizers train on participatory climate and disaster sensitive Village Development Planning/ VRMP and risk sensitive development planning (Grame Niladharis, Development Officers, Samurdhi Officers, Social Service Officers, Village Leaders). As a result of training, they already produced 45 climate resilient village development plans
Result 3: 5 stakeholder groups namely Department of Agrarian Development, Provincial Department of Agriculture, Divisional Secretariats, District Secretariats, SEMA (120 people) reporting enhanced awareness of climate change risks and adaptation measures at National, Provincial, district, divisional and village levels
Result 4: 2 departments viz (a) Provincial Department of Agriculture - North Western Province and (b) Divisional Secretariats – North Western Province providing regular in-house training programs embedded with climate resilient planning tools including climate resilient agriculture development strategic plan, climatic vulnerability maps and resilient village framework.
Result 5: 18,000 people have access to water throughout the year in terms of quantity, quality and timely manner through rehabilitating 34 tanks. Rehabilitation of 34 tanks also improved the water levels of the ground wells.

Target 1: Manual is available Target 2: 400 mobilizers trained on participatory climate and disaster sensitive Village Development Planning/ VRMP process Target 3: 7 stakeholder groups increase awareness on climate change risk Target 4: 6 departments provide in-house training programmes embedded with climate change adaptation Target 5: 17,500 people have access to water throughout the year

Target 1: Manual is available Manual for climate resilient agriculture development training programs was prepared.
Target 2: 400 mobilizers trained on participatory climate and disaster sensitive Village Development Planning/ VRMP process 400 mobilizers (Grama Niladharis, Samurdhi Officers, Agriculture Research and Production Assistants, Agriculture Instructors, Development Officers, Divisional Officers) from Kurunegala, Puttalam and Rathnapura districts
Target 3: 7 stakeholder groups increase awareness on climate change risk Following stakeholder groups showed increased awareness on climate change risks • District and divisional level officers of Provincial Department of Agriculture in Kurunegala, Puttalam and Rathnapura Districts • District and divisional level officers of Department of Agrarian Development in Kurunegala, District • Officers of District Secretariat Offices in Kurunegala, Puttalam and Rathnapura Districts • Divisional Secretariat Officers in Kurunegala, Puttalam and Rathnapura Districts • Commercial farmers in Kurunegala and Puttalam districts • Paddy and Home Gardening farmers in Kurunegala, Puttalam and Rathnapura Districts • Planning Secretariats in Kurunegala, Puttalam and Rathnapura Districts • Target 4: 6 departments provide in-house training programmes embedded with climate change adaptation • Provincial Department of Agriculture – North Western Province • Provincial Department of Agriculture – Sabaragamuwa Province • Department of Agrarian Development • District Secretariats in Kurunegala, Puttalam and Rathnapura districts • Divisional Secretariats in Kurunegala, Puttalam and Rathnapura districts • Planning Secretariats in in Kurunegala, Puttalam and Rathnapura districts
Target 5: 17,500 people have access to water throughout the year • 17,500 people in Maha Nanneriya cascade system has access to water throughout the years as a result of irrigation development works

1). 0 (Energy sector Data Management System is being developed and this system to be integrated with national EnerGIS web-based data collection system. This system is to be introduced to the provincial councils after the necessary training programmes are completed. This is planned for Q4 2017, Q 12018) 2). 46 (Energy full MACC analysis has been completed, and this analysis includes 46 technology-options in the sector. Multi-Criteria Assessment is being performed for the energy sector combining MACC analysis and other socio-economic factors for prioritizing NAMAs) 3). 121 biogas units, 14 solar PV systems, 24 High Efficiency Motors (Approximately another 80-100 biogas units are under development/construction phase. However, small scale biogas programme has not been progressing as anticipated. Therefore, the project is now also promoting medium-large scale units under the programme. Similarly, the expected energy saving and corresponding GHG emission reduction from High Efficiency Motor application in Tea sector is difficult to be realized and Variable Frequency Drives (VFD) as a technology alternative has been considered. This efficiency motor programme has now been replaced with VFD in the same sector, and the procurement approval of 730 VFD units for 95 tea factories has been given. It is expected that these VFD units will be installed in Q1 of 2018. From 14 pilot units, it is found that the Domestic solar PV with battery storage is a costlier GHG emission mitigation technology, and the concept of battery energy storage needs reconsideration. Rooftop solar for government sector (mainly rural schools) is now being considered as an alternative) 4). 0 5). 0 (MRVing protocols and methodologies for the initially selected three technologies; i.e biogas, domestic solar PV, and efficiency motors have been developed. However, field level verification and QA/QC of the proposed methodologies to be tested/improved before actual accounting of Emission Reductions)

National Environment Act and several other Acts and policies exist that support conservation Policy on human elephant conflict exists But National policy & strategy on ESA is not available and Gaps in existing policy is identified in relation to Human Elephant Conflict and elephants residing outside Elephant Conservation Areas (ECAs) ( 2014). Source : prodoc
Collaborative mechanisms between sectors do not exist, Officials/ stakeholders not trained on ESA management and relevant competencies, National guidelines & tools, Biodiversity data in kala oya basin are not available. (2014). Inter sectoral plans do not exist and Biodiversity and ecosystem based activities are not incorporated in land use plans. Populations of globally threatened species & areas of critical habitats managed within Wilpattu and Kala Wewa ESAs to be verified at the ongoing baseline survey, to be completed by April 2017.

1..Review Wild Elephant Mgt & Conservation Policy & Strategy 2. Desk review of existing policies 3. 6 Local management Committees, 2 District Facilitation Committees & National ESA Committee is operational 4. data collection & developing bio diversity integrated land use plans and finalise 8 biodiversity integrated land use plans by planning team & approved by national ESA Committee 5.. 125 key players at national and sub national level of Project Area are trained 6.. National guidelines & Tools to integrate biodiversity conservation and sustainable use into land use planning are formed 8.stakeholders engagement strategy developed 9.Management Plan Wilpattu and Kahalla pallekale prepared, 10. Identify critical biodiversity habitats in ESA 1 and initiate management plans & complete baseline survey

1. Wild Elephant Mgt & Conservation Policy & Strategy is reviewed and draft is ready for another consultation with wider group of stakeholders 2. 6 Local management Committees formed in Kaluwaragaswewa, Wanathawilluwa, Ipalogama, Palagala, Kakirawa, Galnewa and 2 District Facilitation Committees formed in Anuradhapura & Puttalam and all are operational and linked with the National ESA Committee 3. 125 key players at national and sub national level of Project Area are trained 4. National guidelines & Tools to integrate biodiversity conservation into land use planning are formed and validated and ready for printing in 2017 7.data collection & developing bio diversity integrated land use plans in progress 8.stakeholders engagement strategy developed by CEA 9.Management Plan for Wilpattu complex is prepared, 10. Identified critical biodiversity habitats in ESA 1 & completed recon sense survey and demarcated forest patches with high biodiversity importance

1. Desk review of existing environment policies & ESA policy is drafted and cabinet approved 2. Complete Review Wild Elephant Mgt & Conservation Policy & Strategy and cabinet approved 3. Biodiversity integrated Sectoral plans developed for Agriculture, fisheries, tourism sectors 7. 8 approved biodiversity integrated land use plans available 8. 600 people assured engagement based on ESA communication strategy 9. Management Plan for Kahalla Pallekale & Bar Reef is prepared, A buffer zone is demarkated for barreef , 10. 1. Policy Lab - informal coordination mechanism with Prime Minister's Office, National Planning Department (NPD), Department of Project Management and Monitoring (DPMM), Biodiversity Sri Lanka (private sector platform, part of Ceylon Chambers of Commerce), Coordinating Secretariat for Science Technology and Innovation (COSTI), Lirne Asia, UNDP. Headed by the government. To establish and run the Policy Innovation Lab.
2. - Support to the Police Commission – support to the Future Policing conference, which engaged high-level Police Officials and Academics from the SAARC region, enabling knowledge sharing of different strategies adopted by countries in the region to strengthen the role of the police and the relationship between the police and the citizens, as well as reflection on the need for police reforms in Sri Lanka. - Foresight and Innovations Summit – organized with GOSL, involving 4 governments and resource persons for 4 other countries. - JICA and NPD training – for capacity building for provincial development planners using foresight as a value addition tool for development planning. Involved resource people from India.
3. - COSTI Idea Board – strengthening government’s innovation dashboard, to engage citizens’ ideas on development issues. Pilot phase complete and tested. Looking into cost-sharing model, with COSTI committing funds to further develop this.
4. 0
5.- Support to Parliament – the provision of technical assistance for the revision of standing orders of Parliament; the Code of Conduct for Members of Parliament; and research on procedures to be adopted by the Constitutional Council in selecting appointees to Scheduled Offices. Also provided assistance to the constitutional reforms process, through secretariat support to the Public Representations Committee, technical assistance to the Constitutional Assembly’s Steering Committee and other sub-committees on thematic areas covered by a Constitution, and support to set up and maintain the Const
1.: 2 2.: No target set for this year 3.: 1 4.: No target set for this year

1.: 1 multi-stakeholder mechanism was facilitated by the UNDP during 2017. UNDP facilitated the establishment of a coordination mechanism for the Ministry of Mass Media to engage with civil society organizations (CSOs) working on Right to Information based in Colombo, which would be extended to the provinces over time. 2.: 8 recommendations have been recommended. Of the 8 recommendations: 4 accelerators for achieving the SDGs prescribed in the RIA; 3 main recommendations from the 2017 budget analysis for the Parliamentary Select Committee on Sustainable Development; Review of legislation in conflict with the RTI legal regime: 105 pieces of legislation were identified, impacting on reactive and proactive information disclosure. 8 pieces of legislation were prioritized as requiring urgent amendment. 3. 1 initiative has been established in collaboration with the government incorporating South-South Cooperation. As part of its technical assistance on implementing the Right to Information (RTI) to the Ministry of Mass Media, UNDP commissioned the Commonwealth Human Rights Initiative (CHRI), an international non-governmental organisation, to provide comparative experience and good practice from the region and beyond. As part of this collaboration, the CHRI authored a Guidance Note on Operationalizing the Right to Information Act in Sri Lanka: Comparative Experience and Good Practice. The note draws on comparative experience from South Asia and other jurisdictions with a history of implementing similar laws to provide solutions to some of the challenges that might arise in implementing Sri Lanka’s RTI Act. In addition, CHRI also provided technical inputs to the Review of Legislation in Conflict with the RTI Act in Sri Lanka. 4.: No target set for 2017 5. Furthermore, before project board meetings, project teams conduct reviews to assess results and challenges and document learnings.

1. - Strategic analysis/assessment - Secured the technical advisory support of a Senior Conflict advisor based in New York on developing UNDP Sri Lanka’s peacebuilding strategy and based on this, a framework for UNDP’s engagement with the Peacebuilding Fund. 4 recommendations were provided at the end of the mission. - Mid-term Review of the Country Programme Document – 45 recommendations on policy, institutional and systems reforms within the UNDP.
2. Urgent work priorities through the year were not conducive to initiating discussions around establishing a mechanism on learning. However, during the Mid-term Review (MTR) of the Country Programme Document, a core group across clusters and units was identified to regularly engage throughout the process. In addition, the broader group of staff was engaged in key steps, such as sharing of initial findings and recommendations for feedback, as well as identification of potential entry points for the new country programme based on lessons learned.

The planning process and inception phase for this project took a considerably longer period than previously envisaged. Thus as at end December, progress towards outputs had not been achieved. A strategic work plan has been developed and key stakeholders have been consulted. Work in relation to this will begin early next year.
